text:
- With all the talented minds
at the Allen Institute,
cloud technology from AWS,

and the global neuroscience
community contributing
we can change the world.

We've had a really fruitful
collaboration with AWS
to bring together new technologies

that we haven't had access
to in the neuroscience realm.

- The human brain has more
than 100 billion cells.

Finding a specific type
of cells involved in,
for example, Parkinson's disease
or Alzheimer's disease,
is like finding a needle in a haystack.
We're creating one of the most complex
and comprehensive resources in science,
the Brain Knowledge Platform.
By creating a highly precise
and high resolution map of the brain,
we will help researchers to find

that particular needle
they are looking for.

- This complexity has prevented
us from understanding
what the basis of diseases are.

Many of the treatments
actually came from serendipity,
and we have cures for essentially none.

- When I first went into
college, my grandmother started
to get forgetful.

Then was eventually diagnosed
with Alzheimer's disease.
It really motivated me that we can come up
with new kinds of treatments.
The data that we're generating is massive.
To actually sift through it,

we use a lot of machine learning
and AI-based algorithms.
So we're turning to AWS.

- We have about 80 petabytes of
data. That's growing rapidly.
Each piece of that information is critical

because who knows which data
set has that missing connection

that's going to help us understand
the Alzheimer's disease.
So using AI
and ML, we find the connections
between our different data sets.
- By making all the data freely
and openly available to everybody,

we are accelerating the research
across the entire field.

- If we can understand the
specific parts of the brain
that are affected in disease,

we can develop precision
cures.

I view of this project as the
equivalent of the human genome.
All types of brain diseases could be
positively impacted.

- When our understanding of the
human brain truly comes into
focus, the possibilities will be infinite.

- Harnessing all of the amazing
data we now have access to
will help us understand the brain,
understand brain disease,
and drive the next generation of cures.
